old.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: something that is old has existed or been used for a long time
old.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: Some of the houses around here are very old.
The car’s getting old now, and things are starting to go wrong with it.
That story’s as old as the hills (=extremely old).
old.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: someone who is old has lived for a very long time
old.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: I can’t run around like I used to – I must be getting old.
old.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: the care of the old and sick
old.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: used to talk about how long a person or thing has lived or existed
old.translation[0].definitions[3].note.t: somebody is old enough to be his/her/your mother/father (=used to say that someone is too old to be having a sexual relationship with someone else)
old.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: You’re old enough to get your own breakfast now.
I’m not coming skating. I’m too old for that now.
I can’t believe you’re nearly forty years old!
old.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: your old house, job, girlfriend etc is one that you used to have
old.translation[0].definitions[4].note.t: old flame (=someone with whom you used to have a romantic relationship)
old.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: I met up with one of my old girlfriends at the weekend.
My old car was always breaking down.
That happened when we were still in the old house.
old.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: old things are things that are familiar to you because you have seen them or experienced them many times before
old.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: It’s good to get back into the old routine.
I enjoyed seeing all the old familiar faces.
He comes out with the same old excuses every time!
old.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: an old friend, enemy etc is someone you have known for a long time
old.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: Bob’s an old friend of mine.
old.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 3: used to talk about how long a person or thing has lived or existed
old.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[: He was too old for military service.
be old enough to do something
You’re old enough to help with the cooking.
somebody is old enough to know better
He’s old enough to know better, but he went and did it anyway!
somebody is old enough to be somebody’s mother/father
Why would she want to go out with someone who was old enough to be her father?
There are some nice old houses
There are some old nice houses
She was dressed in old black clothes
She was dressed in black old clothes
old.translation[0].note_box[2].sections[: having lived for a long time
I’m too old to learn a new language.
a home for the elderly (=elderly people)
If you are elderly, you may be eligible for financial assistance.
the problems of an ageing population
She had to look after her aged aunt.
an older brother or sister. Elder sounds more formal than older
I’ll be 30 next year – it sounds really ancient!
He’s 60 now, so he’s getting on a bit.
to be too old to do something
Everyone thinks you’re past it when you get to 40.
relating to medical care and treatment for old people
very old – used about things that existed thousands of years ago, or things that look very old
antique furniture, clocks, jewellery etc are old and often valuable
used about traditions, problems, or situations that have existed for a very long time
the age-old tradition of morris dancing
the age-old prejudice against women in positions of power
